displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: You sure as heck don’t give the flu shot after the fact. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: Because nothing’s going to happen. Family Member: Happen. Right. Doctor: But if you know that you’re susceptible to it, you know, something’s going to happen. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: You give the flu shot. You hope to try to prevent it from getting worse. Family Member: Worse. Um hum. Doctor: So the vaccine therapy wakes up your body’s immune system to try to fight the cancer by itself. Family Member: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: We also have information that at least in the, you know, African American men-

Patient: But that doesn’t mean we’re moving in next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re probably going to have some work done. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And stay at dad’s until it’s all done. Doctor: So it might be a couple of months. Patient: No. It won’t be a couple of months. We couldn’t handle a couple of months. Doctor: Okay. We’ll shoot for less than a month. How about that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. How you doing on the XTANDI? Not too bad? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. You look great. But anything compared to last time when you weren’t feeling so hot and your blood sugar was…… YOU LOOK GREAT! (Laughs)

Patient: Yeah I… Doctor: I just - Give me a head’s up so I can talk to Dr. K____ and you know make that transition back. Patient: Uh huh. I see. Doctor: Just so he’s not shocked and you know he’s not panicking and calling me when you’re there in his office as to what happened. Patient: Ha-ha, yeah. Yeah. Family Member: So if his bone scan shows progression, are you gonna be in touch with him then? Doctor: I am. Family Member: Then he will start that? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And either way I think I will give him a head’s up especially – do you know when – do you have an appointment to see him? Patient: No, no, not right now we don’t.

Patient: Yeah, mhm. Doctor: Well, um. I’m sorry that was the case. L-let’s talk about that. I wish I had known that a little earlier. But, the the reason that I’d like to talk about it is because it’s possible that we might need to make a switch in your treatment today anyway. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So um it is likely or or possible that I might be giving you a new prescription today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For a different medication anyway. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um, we’ll have to see um what the PSA test looks like today. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But in the last few months it has been going up. Patient: I know it’s high today. Doctor: How do you know that?

Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh…

Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale. Patient: I like coming here better. Doctor: Yes. Definitely. I mean it’s much more in and out, it’s a smaller place, and there are- Patient: It’s hectic down there. Doctor: Yes. Yes. Patient: Tell you? (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. It is a much bigger place. But it needs to be with the hospital and everything.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: and will continue to. I know G___ asked you a lot about that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: He wrote three pads and… So do you want to see Dr. F__? Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean… Doctor: Yeah it’s okay with me. Family Member: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Uh huh, Yeah I think he’s excellent. I haven’t talked to him in a long time, but he and I are close. We used to talk all the time. Family Member: Okay. Gives you a good reason for you to get back together (Laughs) Doctor: M____. Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there.

Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it?

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven.

Patient: Bonus with what I had in front of me. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And then realized we gotta go. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know? We went to a restaurant and was like, no, we gotta go. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve gotta box this up. You know? As it was I was a little bit late Family Member: You ate half of it. Doctor: No. That’s okay. You should never rush to come here. You know that. You just come when you can safely. I’m not going anywhere. So next time just finish whatever you’ve gotta finish. Patient: Well, we, we, we, started now much late. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame.

Patient: No, up at, uh, Hospital A. I got it a couple of weeks ago, Lupron. Doctor: Do you ever chew tobacco or snuff? Patient: No. (softly) Doctor: Get a flu shot this year? Patient: I did. Doctor: Uh, do you have any sense as to when you did that? Patient: It was in September, late September. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Doin’ good! Doctor: Uh, what’s goin’ on? Jaw still troubling you? Patient: A little bit, yeah. It’s, it’s, uh, right, right in, um in here. Right here. And the teeth are a little bit sensitive, just in spots Doctor: Gotten better or gotten worse?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: That the cancer is shrinking. Doctor: So if his PSA drops. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. Doctor: Because my sense is if you are well and your PSA’s down I assume the cancer is shrinking. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I might need pictures if we can’t your catheter is out. So what’s the problem there? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So most of that really is just plumbing. Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
